awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Exploring the Immunological Priming in Basal Metazoan (Anthozoan)
awd_abstract_narration:
Coral reefs are among the most biologically diverse and economically important ecosystems on the planet. However, they are at risk of demise from ongoing and impending environmental stressors and disease-causing agents. There is a need to understand the mechanisms of resistance to pathogenic stressors by corals if we are to influence the persistence of coral reefs under current challenges. Here a research program will elucidate the specificity, memory and molecular basis of the defense response of corals upon repetitive encounters with pathogens. Understanding how the immune system of these organisms responds to pathogens may offer insights into the resilience of these ecosystems, and potentially may inform remediation of them. One clear implication would be the development of immunization protocols to improve tolerance and survival of corals and their relatives. The proposed research will increase and potentially transform our understanding of the dynamic immunological response of these basal animals, which remains grossly understudied despite the ecological and economic importance of coral reefs. Furthermore, the project will build science capacity through the training and education of the next generation of American and international young scientists. The lead investigator will develop research and educational projects to support K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students within the integrated scope of the project.  A strong emphasis will be placed on developing outreach programs for Hispanic high school students and other minority students from the Miami metropolitan area with the goal of generating interest in science education and facilitating growth in the recruitment and participation of these underrepresented groups in undergraduate fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. An important aspect of this educational project is the synergy between the research laboratory of an early-career scientist, a well-established Hispanic Serving Institution (Florida International University) and the local public school system in Miami-Dade County, all joined in the mission to stimulate interest in science careers through exposure to inspired teaching. 

Coral diseases are of great concern since they have emerged over recent decades as a significant threat to coral reef ecosystems. In order to understand and influence the persistence of coral reefs under current challenges, it is imperative to understand the mechanisms of immunological resistance to pathogens in corals and their relatives (Cnidaria, Anthozoa). The Principal Investigator will elucidate the role of immune priming in the response of anthozoans upon repetitive encounters to infectious agents. The approach uses the sea anemone model Exaiptasia pallida to determine whether the immune system of this organism exhibits specific memory in response to infectious agents, as indicated by accelerated defensive responses upon subsequent exposures to pathogens, a phenomenon that remains largely unknown in basal metazoans. This research also investigates the lasting effect of induced protective response upon multiple repetitive pathogenic encounters. Furthermore, transcriptomic profiles and histological approaches will be used to facilitate the discovery of the molecular and cellular mechanisms underpinning the phenomenon of immune priming.

por.por_cntn:
Coral reefs are incredibly diverse and important ecosystems that face risks from environmental stress and diseases. In this project, we aimed to understand how corals defend themselves against harmful pathogens. We discovered that sea anemones, a type of coral, have a better chance of survival when they have encountered a pathogen before.

Intellectual Merit: 

Key findings of our research include the following: Sea anemones that had encountered a pathogen in less severe conditions were more likely to survive a subsequent, more severe challenge compared to anemones encountering the pathogen for the first time. This suggests that these organisms possess a form of specific memory that helps them respond better to pathogens. These discoveries contribute to the growing understanding that invertebrates have highly adaptable immune systems that can generate new and effective responses based on past experiences. Our findings challenge the previous misconception that organisms lacking B and T cells would also lack an adaptive immune response. We demonstrated that these basal metazoans do indeed exhibit a trained immune response, and we also made efforts to understand the underlying mechanisms of this phenomenon.

In our study, we performed the first-ever comprehensive analysis of proteins in cnidarians, a group that includes sea anemones. Through this analysis, we identified a larger number of genes, involved in various cellular processes, that were more active in anemones previously exposed to a pathogen compared to those that had not encountered it before a second exposure. This suggests that anemones exhibit an initial burst of gene expression activity related to immune defense when they have prior exposure to a pathogen, indicating a form of temporary immune priming. Additionally, our discoveries indicate that immune priming may have evolved much earlier in the evolutionary history of life than previously believed. Understanding how these organisms' immune systems respond to pathogens can provide insights into the resilience of their ecosystems and may guide efforts to restore and protect them. One practical implication of our research is the potential development of immunization protocols to enhance the tolerance and survival of corals and related organisms.

During the latter part of our project, we expanded our investigation to understand how environmental factors impact the immune response of cnidarians, specifically focusing on reef-building corals. This exploration was driven by the recognition that these corals face numerous threats, including global climate change and local stressors like nutrient pollution. Our research uncovered that nutrient pollution hampers the coral immune system's ability to combat microbial infections that occur following physical injuries from predation. This means that higher nutrient levels in the water suppress crucial pathways in the coral immune system, leading to an increase in coral disease and subsequent mortality on reefs affected by nutrient enrichment. Our findings underscore the urgency of addressing and mitigating nutrient pollution on coral reefs to protect their immune responses and combat the detrimental effects of nutrient enrichment on coral health.

Broader Impact: 

In addition to our scientific research, this project made significant contributions to the development of scientific capacity by providing training and education opportunities to young scientists from the United States and around the world. We designed research and educational initiatives to support students at various educational levels, including K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students, all integrated within the project's scope. We placed particular emphasis on outreach programs tailored for Hispanic high school students and other minority students residing in the Miami metropolitan area. The objective was to foster interest in science education and facilitate increased recruitment and participation of these underrepresented groups in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields at the undergraduate level.

One notable program we implemented was the Scientific Adventure high school program, which took place every summer for a duration of three weeks. During this program, students had the opportunity to delve into the fields of microbiology and genetics, gaining hands-on experience and learning directly from experts in the field.

During the later phase of the project, starting from the summer of 2019, we shifted our focus towards university undergraduate students at FIU (Florida International University). In this stage, we transformed several traditional General Biology labs into fully research-based teaching laboratories. This program, known as UBIOS (Undergraduate Biological Investigations of Symbiosis), has already benefited over 800 students, providing them with valuable educational experiences. Through these efforts, we aimed to nurture scientific talent, increase diversity in STEM fields, and contribute to the education and training of future generations of scientists.

Another significant aspect of this educational project was the collaboration and synergy between various entities. It involved the research laboratory of an early-career scientist, the well-established Hispanic Serving Institution of Florida International University, and the local public school system in Miami-Dade County. Together, these entities shared a common mission of fostering interest in science careers by providing exposure to inspired teaching.
